canonical_explanation.text: Every household generates garbage (waste). This garbage can be classified into two types based on whether it decomposes naturally. Biodegradable waste is waste that can be broken down by microorganisms into simpler substances. Examples include food scraps, paper, cotton, dead leaves, and animal dung. Non-biodegradable waste cannot be easily broken down by microorganisms and stays in the environment for a very long time. Examples include plastic, glass, metal cans, and polythene bags. Composting is the process of converting biodegradable waste into useful manure by letting microorganisms decompose it. Vermicomposting is composting with the help of redworms (earthworms), which eat organic waste and produce nutrient-rich compost. The 3Rs — Reduce (use less), Reuse (use again without changing), and Recycle (process waste to make new products) — are important principles for waste management. Burning garbage causes harmful air pollution, and dumping in landfills takes up valuable land space. Proper waste management through segregation, composting, and the 3Rs helps protect our environment.
rules: Biodegradable waste decomposes naturally by microorganisms (food scraps, paper, cotton, leaves).
Non-biodegradable waste does not decompose easily (plastic, glass, metal, polythene).
Composting converts organic waste into useful manure.
Vermicomposting uses redworms to convert organic waste into compost.
The 3Rs: Reduce (use less), Reuse (use again), Recycle (make new products from waste).
Burning garbage pollutes the air with harmful gases.
Landfills are sites where garbage is dumped and buried.
Waste should be segregated into wet (biodegradable) and dry (non-biodegradable) categories.
Plastic is a major environmental concern because it is non-biodegradable.
Paper can be recycled to make new paper products.

questions.question_text: Waste materials that can be broken down by microorganisms into simpler substances are called:
questions.explanation_correct: Biodegradable waste is waste that can be broken down (decomposed) by microorganisms like bacteria and fungi into simpler, harmless substances. Examples include food scraps, paper, and dead leaves.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Non-biodegradable waste cannot be broken down by microorganisms. Toxic and industrial waste are specific categories. Waste that microorganisms can decompose is specifically called biodegradable waste.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a non-biodegradable waste?
questions.explanation_correct: A plastic bag is non-biodegradable because it cannot be broken down by microorganisms. Plastic stays in the environment for hundreds of years without decomposing.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Banana peel, paper, and cotton cloth are all biodegradable — they can be decomposed by microorganisms. Plastic bags are non-biodegradable and persist in the environment for very long periods.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a biodegradable waste?
questions.explanation_correct: Vegetable peels are biodegradable because they can be decomposed by microorganisms. They break down naturally and can be composted to make useful manure for plants.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Glass bottles, aluminium cans, and plastic wrappers are all non-biodegradable. Vegetable peels are the only biodegradable item here, as they decompose naturally.

questions.question_text: Plastic is biodegradable and breaks down easily in the environment.
questions.explanation_correct: This is false. Plastic is non-biodegradable — it does not break down easily. It can persist in the environment for hundreds or even thousands of years, causing serious pollution to land and water.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Plastic is non-biodegradable. It does not decompose easily and remains in the environment for a very long time, making it a major environmental concern.

questions.question_text: Which of the following groups contains ONLY biodegradable items?
questions.explanation_correct: Fruit peels, dead leaves, and cotton are all biodegradable — they can all be decomposed by microorganisms. The other options contain at least one non-biodegradable item.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A has plastic (non-biodegradable). Option C has glass and metal (non-biodegradable). Option D has polythene (non-biodegradable). Only option B has all biodegradable items.

questions.question_text: After a birthday party, the following waste was generated: paper plates, plastic cups, leftover cake, and balloons. Which of these is biodegradable?
questions.explanation_correct: Paper plates (made from paper) and leftover cake (food item) are biodegradable — they can be decomposed by microorganisms. Plastic cups and balloons (usually rubber or plastic) are non-biodegradable.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Plastic cups are non-biodegradable. Balloons are usually made of rubber or plastic and are non-biodegradable. Only paper plates and leftover cake are biodegradable.

questions.question_text: A landfill is:

options.text: A factory that makes useful products from waste
A place where garbage is dumped and buried
A garden where compost is made

questions.explanation_correct: A landfill is a designated area where garbage is collected, dumped, and buried under soil. Landfills are commonly used for waste disposal, but they take up large areas of land and can pollute soil and groundwater.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A landfill is not a factory, garden, or water treatment plant. It is specifically a waste disposal site where garbage is dumped and covered with soil.

questions.question_text: What is the main problem with burning garbage in the open?

options.text: It produces harmful smoke that pollutes the air
It makes the garbage smell worse

questions.explanation_correct: Burning garbage in the open produces harmful smoke, toxic gases, and particulate matter that pollute the air. This can cause respiratory problems and contribute to air pollution, which is harmful to both humans and the environment.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The main problem is not time, smell, or water use. The serious issue is that burning garbage releases harmful smoke and toxic gases into the air, causing air pollution and health problems.

questions.question_text: Why should we segregate waste into different bins?

options.text: To make the bins look colourful
To make garbage collection easier and enable proper treatment of different types of waste
To reduce the number of bins needed
Because the government forces us to

questions.explanation_correct: Segregating waste helps in proper waste management. Biodegradable waste can be composted, while non-biodegradable waste can be recycled or disposed of properly. Mixing them makes treatment difficult.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The purpose of segregation is not about appearance, reducing bins, or just following rules. It enables efficient waste treatment — composting biodegradable waste and recycling non-biodegradable waste.

questions.question_text: Waste is usually segregated into two bins: green bin and blue bin. What type of waste goes into the green bin?

options.text: All types of waste mixed together

questions.explanation_correct: The green bin is for wet/biodegradable waste such as food scraps, vegetable peels, and leftover food. The blue bin is for dry/non-biodegradable waste like plastic, glass, and metal.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Plastic, glass, metal, and rubber go in the blue (dry waste) bin. The green bin is specifically for wet, biodegradable waste like food scraps and organic matter.

questions.question_text: Composting is the process of:

options.text: Burning waste to reduce its volume
Converting biodegradable waste into useful manure
Melting plastic waste to make new products

questions.explanation_correct: Composting is the process of converting biodegradable waste (like food scraps, leaves, and garden waste) into nutrient-rich manure through decomposition by microorganisms. This compost can be used to enrich soil for gardening.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Composting is not burning, landfilling, or melting plastic. It is specifically the natural decomposition of organic (biodegradable) waste into useful manure by microorganisms.

questions.question_text: Vermicomposting uses which organisms to break down organic waste?
questions.explanation_correct: Vermicomposting uses redworms (a type of earthworm) to break down organic waste. The worms eat the waste, digest it, and produce worm castings (vermicompost), which is an excellent nutrient-rich fertilizer.
questions.explanation_incorrect: While bacteria also help in decomposition, vermicomposting specifically uses redworms (earthworms). The prefix 'vermi' means worm. Houseflies and ants are not used in composting.

questions.question_text: Which of the following waste items can be used for composting?
questions.explanation_correct: Vegetable and fruit peels are biodegradable and can be used for composting. They will be broken down by microorganisms into nutrient-rich compost. Glass, plastic, and metal cannot be composted.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Glass, plastic, and metal are non-biodegradable and cannot be composted. Only biodegradable waste like vegetable and fruit peels can be used for composting.

questions.question_text: Ramu wants to set up a vermicomposting pit at home. Which of the following should he NOT put in the pit?
questions.explanation_correct: Plastic wrappers should NOT be put in a vermicomposting pit because they are non-biodegradable. Redworms cannot eat or break down plastic. Only biodegradable organic waste like fruit peels, vegetable scraps, and dried leaves should go in.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Fruit peels, vegetable scraps, and dried leaves are all biodegradable and suitable for vermicomposting. Plastic wrappers cannot be decomposed by worms and should not be added.

questions.question_text: The compost produced by vermicomposting is useful because:

options.text: It can be burned as fuel
It is rich in nutrients and can be used as natural fertilizer for plants
It can be eaten by humans
It can be used to make plastic

questions.explanation_correct: Vermicompost is rich in nutrients and is an excellent natural fertilizer for plants. It improves soil quality and helps plants grow healthy. It is a much better alternative to chemical fertilizers.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Vermicompost is not used as fuel, food for humans, or for making plastic. Its primary use is as a natural, nutrient-rich fertilizer that enriches soil and promotes healthy plant growth.

questions.question_text: What does the 'Reduce' in the 3Rs stand for?

options.text: Using less and avoiding waste generation

questions.explanation_correct: 'Reduce' means using less and avoiding the generation of waste in the first place. For example, using cloth bags instead of plastic bags, buying only what you need, and avoiding disposable items.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Using the same item again is 'Reuse'. Making new products from waste is 'Recycle'. 'Reduce' specifically means using less to prevent waste from being generated.

questions.question_text: Using a glass jar that came with jam to store spices is an example of:
questions.explanation_correct: Using a jam jar to store spices is an example of 'Reuse' — using an item again for a different purpose without changing it. Reusing extends the life of products and reduces waste.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Reduce means using less. Recycle means processing waste into new products. This is specifically reuse — using the same jar again for a new purpose without any processing.

questions.question_text: Converting old newspapers into new paper is an example of:
questions.explanation_correct: Converting old newspapers into new paper is recycling — processing waste material to create a new product. Recycling saves resources and reduces the amount of waste going to landfills.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Reduce is using less. Reuse is using again without changing. Composting is for biodegradable waste. Converting old paper into new paper involves processing, which is recycling.

questions.question_text: Recycling helps in reducing the amount of waste that goes to landfills.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. When waste materials like paper, glass, and metal are recycled into new products, they do not end up in landfills. This reduces the amount of waste in landfills and conserves natural resources.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is correct. Recycling diverts waste from landfills by converting it into useful new products, reducing both waste volume and the need for raw materials.

questions.question_text: Priya carries a cloth bag to the market instead of using plastic bags. This is an example of:
questions.explanation_correct: Using a cloth bag instead of plastic bags is both 'Reduce' (reducing the use of plastic bags) and 'Reuse' (the cloth bag is used again and again). It avoids creating plastic waste.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This action involves both reducing (less plastic bag usage) and reusing (the same cloth bag repeatedly). It is not recycling because no waste is being processed into a new product.

questions.question_text:
A student sorted the following items:
Bin 1: Orange peels, tea leaves, eggshells
Bin 2: Plastic bottles, glass pieces, metal spoons
How did the student sort the waste?
questions.explanation_correct: The student sorted waste into biodegradable (Bin 1: orange peels, tea leaves, eggshells — all decompose naturally) and non-biodegradable (Bin 2: plastic bottles, glass, metal — do not decompose easily).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The sorting is not by colour, size, or weight. It is by biodegradability: Bin 1 has items that decompose (biodegradable) and Bin 2 has items that do not decompose (non-biodegradable).

questions.question_text: Which is the BEST method to deal with biodegradable kitchen waste at home?

options.text: Mix it with non-biodegradable waste and send to landfill

questions.explanation_correct: The best method for biodegradable kitchen waste is composting. It converts waste into useful manure, does not pollute the environment, and reduces the amount of waste going to landfills.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Burning causes air pollution. Throwing in drains blocks them and pollutes water. Sending to landfills wastes useful organic matter. Composting is the most environmentally friendly option.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a problem associated with landfills?

options.text: They take up large areas of land
They produce foul smell and attract flies

questions.explanation_correct: Landfills cause multiple problems: they take up large areas of land (reducing available space), can contaminate groundwater with harmful substances, and produce foul smells while attracting flies and pests.
questions.explanation_incorrect: All the listed problems are associated with landfills. They occupy valuable land, contaminate groundwater through leaching, and create foul smells and pest problems. All options are correct.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is the CORRECT reason why plastic is harmful to the environment?

options.text: Plastic is non-biodegradable and stays in the environment for hundreds of years
Plastic is too soft to be useful
Plastic dissolves in water and pollutes it

questions.explanation_correct: Plastic is harmful because it is non-biodegradable — it does not decompose naturally and stays in the environment for hundreds or thousands of years. It pollutes land, water, and harms animals that mistake it for food.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Plastic's cost and softness are not the environmental concerns. Plastic does not dissolve in water (that is part of the problem). The main issue is that it is non-biodegradable and persists in the environment for extremely long periods.

questions.question_text: In vermicomposting, redworms prefer to eat:

options.text: Rotting fruits, vegetables, and other organic matter

questions.explanation_correct: Redworms eat rotting (decaying) fruits, vegetables, and other organic matter. They digest this material and convert it into nutrient-rich worm castings (vermicompost). They cannot eat non-biodegradable materials.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Redworms cannot eat plastic, glass, metal, or rubber (non-biodegradable). They do not eat just sand and soil. They specifically eat organic (biodegradable) matter like rotting fruits and vegetables.

questions.question_text: Amit donates his old clothes to charity instead of throwing them away. This practice is an example of:
questions.explanation_correct: Donating old clothes to charity is an example of 'Reuse' — the clothes are used again by someone else without being processed. This extends the useful life of the product and reduces waste.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Reduce would be buying fewer clothes. Recycle would be processing old clothes into new material. Donating clothes for others to use is specifically reusing.

questions.question_text: Which of the following items takes the LONGEST time to decompose in the environment?
questions.explanation_correct: A plastic bottle takes the longest to decompose — over 450 years. This is much longer than banana peels (weeks), paper (months), or wool (years). This is why plastic pollution is such a serious environmental concern.
questions.explanation_incorrect: All the times given are approximately correct, but plastic takes by far the longest — over 450 years. This extreme persistence in the environment is what makes plastic waste so harmful.

questions.question_text:
Assertion: We should not burn plastic waste.
Reason: Burning plastic releases harmful toxic gases that pollute the air and are dangerous to health.

options.text: Both assertion and reason are correct, and reason explains the assertion
Both assertion and reason are correct, but reason does not explain the assertion
Assertion is correct but reason is incorrect
Assertion is incorrect but reason is correct

questions.explanation_correct: The assertion is correct — we should not burn plastic. The reason is also correct — burning plastic releases harmful toxic gases (like dioxins and furans) that pollute the air and are dangerous to human health. The reason explains the assertion.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Both statements are correct. Burning plastic produces toxic fumes that are hazardous to health, which is exactly why we should not burn plastic waste. The reason correctly explains the assertion.

questions.question_text: Which of the following actions follows the principle of 'Reduce'?

options.text: Using old newspapers to wrap gifts
Turning off the tap when not using water
Sending old metal cans to a recycling plant
Donating old books to a library

questions.explanation_correct: Turning off the tap when not using water is an example of 'Reduce' — using less of a resource. Reducing consumption is the first and most important step in waste management.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Using old newspapers to wrap gifts is 'Reuse'. Sending cans to recycling is 'Recycle'. Donating books is 'Reuse'. Turning off the tap to use less water is 'Reduce'.

questions.question_text: In India, waste is commonly collected by municipal corporations. Which method should they use FIRST before sending waste to a landfill?

options.text: Segregate waste and compost biodegradable waste; recycle non-biodegradable waste
Dump everything directly in the ocean
Mix all waste together and bury it

questions.explanation_correct: Before using landfills, waste should be segregated. Biodegradable waste should be composted, and non-biodegradable waste should be recycled. Only the remaining waste that cannot be composted or recycled should go to landfills.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Burning waste pollutes air. Dumping in oceans pollutes water and is illegal. Mixing all waste wastes recyclable and compostable materials. The correct approach is segregation, composting, and recycling first.

questions.question_text: Waste that does NOT decompose easily by the action of microorganisms is called _______ waste.
questions.explanation_correct: Waste that does not decompose easily by microorganisms is called non-biodegradable waste. Examples include plastic, glass, metal, and polythene, which persist in the environment for a very long time.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Biodegradable waste does decompose. Organic and natural wastes are usually biodegradable. Non-biodegradable is the specific term for waste that does not decompose easily.

questions.question_text: A school wants to start a vermicomposting project. Which of the following steps is MOST important?

options.text: Collect all types of waste, including plastic
Use only biodegradable organic waste and provide redworms
Add chemical fertilizers to speed up the process
Keep the pit in direct sunlight all day

questions.explanation_correct: For vermicomposting, it is essential to use only biodegradable organic waste (like fruit and vegetable peels) and provide redworms. Plastic and chemicals should not be added, and the pit should be kept in a cool, shaded area.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Plastic should never be added. Chemicals can harm the worms. Direct sunlight can overheat and kill the worms. The most important step is providing only biodegradable waste and the right type of worms.

questions.question_text: Which of the 3Rs is considered the MOST effective in reducing waste?
questions.explanation_correct: 'Reduce' is the most effective because if we use less in the first place, less waste is generated. Prevention is better than cure — it is better to not create waste than to deal with it later through reuse or recycling.
questions.explanation_incorrect: While all 3Rs are important, Reduce is the most effective because it prevents waste from being created in the first place. Reuse and recycle deal with waste after it is generated, but reducing avoids waste creation altogether.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is an example of non-biodegradable waste that can be recycled?
questions.explanation_correct: Aluminium cans are non-biodegradable but can be recycled. They can be melted and reformed into new aluminium products. Recycling aluminium saves energy and natural resources.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Fruit peels, dead leaves, and cotton cloth are all biodegradable (they decompose). Aluminium cans are non-biodegradable but recyclable — they can be melted and made into new products.

questions.question_text: Where does the garbage collected from our homes usually end up?
questions.explanation_correct: Most of the garbage collected from homes ends up in landfills — designated areas where waste is dumped and buried. This is the most common method of waste disposal in India.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Garbage does not go to schools or hospitals. While some waste goes to recycling factories, most household garbage in India ends up in landfills.

questions.question_text: Vermicompost is a type of chemical fertilizer.
questions.explanation_correct: This is false. Vermicompost is a natural (organic) fertilizer, not a chemical fertilizer. It is produced by the decomposition of organic waste by redworms and is much safer for the environment than chemical fertilizers.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Vermicompost is NOT a chemical fertilizer. It is a natural, organic fertilizer produced by earthworms breaking down organic waste. It is an eco-friendly alternative to chemical fertilizers.

questions.question_text: Which of the following actions is the BEST example of recycling?

options.text: Writing on both sides of paper
Melting old glass bottles to make new glass items
Switching off lights when leaving a room

questions.explanation_correct: Melting old glass bottles to make new glass items is recycling — processing waste material to create new products. Writing on both sides is reduce/reuse, refillable bottle is reuse, and switching off lights is reduce.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Writing on both sides is reuse. A refillable bottle is reuse. Switching off lights is reduce. Only melting old glass to make new items involves processing waste into new products — which is recycling.

questions.question_text: A farmer uses cow dung to produce manure for his field. Cow dung is classified as:
questions.explanation_correct: Cow dung is biodegradable waste because it can be decomposed by microorganisms. When composted, it produces useful manure rich in nutrients for plants. It is one of the best natural fertilizers.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Cow dung is organic material that decomposes naturally, making it biodegradable. It is not toxic, electronic, or non-biodegradable. It is one of the most commonly used biodegradable materials for composting.

questions.question_text: Which of the following disposal methods is MOST harmful to the environment?

options.text: Burning all types of waste in the open

questions.explanation_correct: Burning all types of waste in the open is the most harmful method because it releases toxic gases, smoke, and harmful particles into the air, causing air pollution and health problems. Composting, recycling, and vermicomposting are all environmentally friendly methods.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Composting, recycling, and vermicomposting are all eco-friendly methods. Burning waste in the open is the most harmful because it produces toxic smoke, harmful gases, and contributes to air pollution.

questions.question_text:
Match the action with the correct R:
(i) Using both sides of a paper — (P) Recycle
(ii) Making a pencil holder from an old plastic bottle — (Q) Reduce
(iii) Sending old newspapers to a factory to make new paper — (R) Reuse
questions.explanation_correct: Using both sides of paper = Reduce (using less paper). Making a pencil holder from old bottle = Reuse (using the item again differently). Sending newspapers to factory for new paper = Recycle (processing into new product).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct matches are: using both sides = Reduce (less paper consumed), pencil holder from old bottle = Reuse (repurposing), newspapers to factory = Recycle (processing into new paper). Only option A is correct.

questions.question_text: Polythene bags are commonly used for carrying groceries. Why are they a major environmental concern?

options.text: They are too thin and tear easily
They are non-biodegradable and clog drains, harm animals, and pollute soil
They are too heavy to carry

questions.explanation_correct: Polythene bags are a major environmental concern because they are non-biodegradable. They do not decompose, clog drainage systems causing floods, harm animals that eat them, and pollute soil and water bodies.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The concern is not about their thinness, cost, or weight. The environmental problem is that they are non-biodegradable, persist for hundreds of years, clog drains, harm animals, and pollute land and water.

questions.question_text: What conditions do redworms need to survive in a vermicomposting pit?
questions.explanation_correct: Redworms need cool, dark, and moist conditions to thrive. They do not survive in extreme heat, direct sunlight, or very dry conditions. The vermicomposting pit should be kept shaded and moist.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Direct sunlight and dry conditions will kill the worms. Very hot or freezing conditions are also harmful. Redworms thrive in cool, dark, and moist environments.

questions.question_text: Which of the following items should go into the blue (dry waste) bin?
questions.explanation_correct: An empty plastic bottle is dry, non-biodegradable waste and should go in the blue bin. Leftover rice, fruit peels, and tea leaves are wet, biodegradable waste and should go in the green bin.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Leftover rice, fruit peels, and tea leaves are all wet/biodegradable waste for the green bin. Only the empty plastic bottle is dry/non-biodegradable waste that belongs in the blue bin.

questions.question_text: A student wants to practice the 3Rs at school. Which combination of actions covers all three Rs?

options.text: Use less paper (Reduce), use old boxes for storage (Reuse), and send old paper for making new paper (Recycle)
Buy more snacks, throw everything in one bin, and burn the waste
Use only new items, throw old ones away, and dump in a river
Collect all waste and send it to a landfill

questions.explanation_correct: Using less paper = Reduce. Using old boxes for storage = Reuse. Sending old paper to make new paper = Recycle. This combination covers all three Rs and is the most environmentally responsible approach.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Options B, C, and D involve wasteful or harmful practices. Only option A correctly demonstrates all three Rs: Reduce, Reuse, and Recycle.

questions.question_text: Which of the following correctly distinguishes biodegradable from non-biodegradable waste?

options.text: Biodegradable waste is always from plants; non-biodegradable is always from animals
Biodegradable waste can be broken down by microorganisms; non-biodegradable waste cannot
Biodegradable waste is wet; non-biodegradable waste is dry
Biodegradable waste is heavy; non-biodegradable waste is light

questions.explanation_correct: The key distinction is that biodegradable waste can be broken down (decomposed) by microorganisms, while non-biodegradable waste cannot. This is the defining difference, not source, moisture, or weight.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Biodegradable waste can come from both plants and animals (option A wrong). While wet/dry is a common sorting method, it is not the definition (option C wrong). Weight is irrelevant (option D wrong). The correct distinction is decomposition by microorganisms.

questions.question_text: Which of the following would make the BEST compost?

options.text: Kitchen waste like vegetable peels and leftover food

questions.explanation_correct: Kitchen waste like vegetable peels and leftover food is ideal for composting. It is biodegradable and rich in organic matter that microorganisms can easily break down into nutrient-rich compost.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Plastic, metal, glass, rubber, batteries, and electronic waste are all non-biodegradable and cannot be composted. Only organic kitchen waste like vegetable peels and leftover food can be composted.

questions.question_text: What does the 'Recycle' in the 3Rs mean?

options.text: Processing waste materials to make new useful products

questions.explanation_correct: 'Recycle' means collecting waste materials and processing them to make new useful products. For example, old newspapers can be recycled to make new paper, and old glass can be melted to make new glass items.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Throwing waste in a bin is disposal. Using less is Reduce. Burning waste is harmful disposal. Recycle specifically means processing waste materials into new products.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is the CORRECT order of preference for waste management?
questions.explanation_correct: The correct priority order is: Reduce (use less) → Reuse (use again) → Recycle (make new products from waste) → Landfill (as last resort). Prevention is always better than treatment.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The best approach starts with prevention: Reduce first, then Reuse, then Recycle, and only as a last resort, send to landfill. Burning should generally be avoided. Only option B shows the correct priority order.

questions.question_text: Which of the following groups contains ONLY non-biodegradable waste?

options.text: Plastic bags, glass bottles, tin cans

questions.explanation_correct: Plastic bags, glass bottles, and tin cans are all non-biodegradable — none of them can be easily broken down by microorganisms. The other options contain at least one biodegradable item.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option B has food waste and paper (biodegradable). Option C has all biodegradable items. Option D has all biodegradable items. Only option A contains exclusively non-biodegradable waste.

questions.question_text: Why is it important to teach children about waste management and the 3Rs?

options.text: So they can get better marks in exams
Because it helps protect the environment for future generations
Because garbage is interesting to study
So they can work in waste management companies

questions.explanation_correct: Teaching children about waste management and the 3Rs is important because it helps them develop responsible habits that protect the environment. If we do not manage waste properly, it will harm the environment, animals, and future generations.
questions.explanation_incorrect: While exam marks and career opportunities may be secondary benefits, the primary reason is environmental protection. Proper waste management ensures a cleaner, healthier planet for current and future generations.
